captions.text: - HELLO, EVERYONE.
I'M JOSEPH CARMICHAEL.
OTIS IS--WAS MY FATHER.

BUT WE ARE NOT HERE TODAY
TO MOURN HIS DEATH,
BUT TO CELEBRATE HIS LIFE.

WE KNEW OTIS AS A TEACHER,
A COMMUNITY LEADER,

A ROLE MODEL, A HUSBAND,
AND A FATHER.

NOW, I THOUGHT
IT WOULD BE NICE

TO SHARE SOMETHING ABOUT HIM
Y'ALL MAY NOT HAVE KNOWN.
WHEN MY FATHER WAS YOUNGER,

HE WAS AN ACTOR
IN HOLLYWOOD.
GOING THROUGH MY DAD'S THINGS,

I FOUND THIS REEL OF HIS WORK
AS AN ACTOR.
I HAVEN'T SEEN IT YET,

BUT I THOUGHT
IT WOULD BE FUN TO WATCH,
HERE WITH ALL OF YOU TODAY.
THANK YOU.

- [gasps]
WHERE ARE MY PIES?

RIBBLES, WHERE ARE THE PIES
I PUT ON MY WINDOWSILL?

- WHY, I DON'T KNOW,
MRS. CARUTHERS.

WHY WOULD ANYONE
WANT TO STEAL

ONE OF YOUR DELICIOUS
BLUEBERRY PIES?

- [snaps]
HEY.

SEE TO IT YOU SHINE
THOSE SHOES UP NICE, BOY.

- YES, SIR,
YOU BEST BE BELIEVING I WILL!

I'LL SHINE YOUR SHOES BLACKER
THAN MY MAMA'S BOOTY.
[all gasp]
[laughs]
[yelling]
OOGA-BOOGA!

OOGA-BOOGA SHOO!
OOGA-BOOGA SHOO!

OOGA-BOOGA!
- OH, HELL NO!

- OOGA-BOOGA SHOO!
[yelling]

- IN 1964,
MY FATHER MARCHED

WITH MARTIN LUTHER KING JR.
AND HARRY BELAFONTE

ALONG WITH OTHER RENOWNED
CIVIL RIGHTS LEADERS.

comments.text:
This is why you always watch something before you show it to other people. 
In my case i found a box in my great grandfathers closet, it had the words 
war memories on it. I opened it and found out my great grandfather was a 
nazi. He had an SS uniform in the box with several medals and pictures of 
him wearing it. One picture was of him holding a gun to a womans head while 
she was giving him a blow job. He also had a journal that went into graphic 
detail his actions during the war. Needless to say i burned all of it. But 
i sold the medals to an antique store.﻿

comments.text:
'Racism' is merely a word used much like the term "n-word" The entire 
concept of "n-word" is to keep the initial demeaning european context of 
'nigger' as being associated with black people, alive in our current 
present. 'Racism' is utilized to a similar effect to keep the naturally 
savage and barbaric nature of so-claimed "white" people, (currently 
accepted to be "something of the past"....i.e. "we're not like that 
anymore") relevant in the present day and time without attesting to the 
apparent lack of humanity that one observes and inquires of when viewing 
their demonic behaviors (*see Cynical African website for clarity). When 
caucasians behave in ill ways towards non-"white" people they are not being 
"racist" they are being their natural evil selves. Don't call these rejects 
racist its not nice nor accurate.

Cheers﻿
comments.author: Nat Turner

comments.text:
+Nat Turner You are making a big error in the definition because you dont 
have to be in a position of power to be racist and racists can hold 
positive views "asians are smart" or "all jews are lawyers or doctors" but 
the fact that you assume one or more things about members of a ethnic group 
just because of their ethnic group makes it racist.

I'll agree without a doubt that things are very bleak for a lot of black 
people in the states. I also agree with you about people in general not 
bending down to adversity though in my case that mostly goes for women. I 
come from an almost matriachal family and I could never stand to be around 
the sissy kind of women that couldnt stand up for themselves, I'll leave it 
to you to see if that makes any sense in comparison.

And I'm sad to say that your views on europeans just arent true, especially 
not in times like these, a bad economy for many years only makes two things 
happen in europe. Xenophobia and facism. You have things like The Golden 
Dawn in Greece, Front Nationale in France, Sverigedemokraterna here in 
Sweden, British National Party in the U.K and so forth.
comments.author: TheHuggableMrHuggles

comments.text:

comments.author: Nat Turner

comments.text:
+TheHuggableMrHuggles for me to be "racist" I must have the power of my 
thoughts towards a certain people to have the ability to ADVERSELY affect 
their PHYSICAL lives and livelyhood. Blacks ain't got that kind of power in 
THIS land, but "whites" do. The way that they THINK about us can adversely 
affect our PHYSICAL lives and livelyhood. I might be an asshole but I could 
NEVER be "racist". And for the record I don't have a problem with y'alls 
evilness...you are who you are and I WANT you to be who you are...I just 
don't want my people to be bitches when dealing with y'all.
comments.author: Nat Turner

comments.text:
+Nat Turner So all in all you're saying that you're not a racist and then 
sticking to your guns. You could have saved yourself time just typing "I'm 
not racist, BUT...".

Let me guess that you're from the U.S the country where that kind of 
terrible logic regarding racism usually emanates. Though its really not 
singled out there here(Sweden) for example the "I'm not racist, BUT..." 
types talk like that about muslims, my redneck shit for brains brother 
in-law is one of those guys that assumes that all muslims are arabs and all 
arabs are evil. The exact same reasoning you are applying to caucasians but 
I doubt you will see them as comparable and rather see that as a proof for 
your view of white people as evil.
comments.author: TheHuggableMrHuggles

NOTHING.... I'm saying that "I" declare such acts and history as 
'evil'...there might be another word for it...but in my search I've yet to 
find one that suffices. And yes I have EARNESTLY searched...I don't wish to 
question the humanity of a certain people, but THAT is what comes into 
context inquiry when viewing the psychology that caucaisians tend to 
exhibit. I also find that the non-racist ones exhibit this trait more 
severely than those who could be considered "openly" racist. This current 
present, the past history, and the projected future all shows an innate 
evilism that pervades all caucasian action...even when they mean 
well...there is going to be more CON than PRO as the result and I bet my 
life that THEY'LL be the chief benefiter of whatever profit that may be 
produced from the process.

comments.text:
At 1:03 the screen reads Agent: Moishe Goldfarb. That seems like a low-blow 
at jews. I imagine the implication being that jewish hollywood agents are 
somehow to blame for the racially degrading roles that blacks were forced 
to play in that era. How ironic, that in comedy skit that helps shed light 
on offensive black stereotypes from the past, Key and Peele choose to 
perpetuate a contemporary jewish stereotype: that of the jewish hollywood 
agent/director/producer etc. who exploits and degrades blacks. Pretty 
disappointing. ﻿
comments.author: br luck

comments.text:
I didn't notice that at first, but couldn't you look at it as an ironic jab 
at ethnic stereotyping, just like they've done with black stereotyping in 
this sketch, rather than something malicious. The whole sketch is meant to 
be poking fun at stereotyping so having the Jewish agent's name on the reel 
is just an extension of that, only from another perspective.
comments.author: Shaun Feldman

comments.text: Oh jesus christ man. It's a comedy sketch
comments.author: IAN 4000

comments.text:
I enjoy most key and peele sketches actually. They poke fun mainly at black 
stereotypes which i think can be cathartic for members of particular ethnic 
group to poke fun at their own stereotypes. Lets just say if two white guys 
performed many of their sketches im sure many of us would find them 
offensive. Poking fun of a different groups ethnic stereotyoes can be funny 
too and when done tastefully i take no offense. Its very hart to articulate 
why one joke feels acceptabe and in good fun, and another one feels 
insulting and offensive.﻿ I wish i was better able to explain why, for me, 
this moishe goldfarb joke falls into the latter category.
comments.author: br luck

comments.text:
A more realistic comparison would be a white civil rights pastor, that was 
a closeted kkk member (or child molester/porno enthusiast, or a gay man, 
etc), but you got what I meant. But I will concede, the negative reaction 
the audience displayed (in the skit) had nothing to do with sensitivity. 
They didn't think his Hollywood career did anything to tarnish his civil 
rights activism, not at all.
comments.author: Bob Loblaw

comments.text:
+Melissa M​ So you are going to completely ignore my white male 
conservative porn star comparison? Whatever. ﻿All you did was copy your 
previous responce and the original post. Again, whatever.
comments.author: Bob Loblaw

comments.text:
+Bob Loblaw
I'm pretty sure I don't need a play by play of the skit. I fully understand 
why the funeral attendees are (would be) upset. Perhaps I should explain 
further: I was referencing  your 'overly sensitive black people' 
interpretation. And I'm fairly certain that is not the purpose of this 
skit. I think the other commenter (Michael Sandoval) was spot on with his 
interpretation. Further to that, I was saying that Key & Peele were more 
than likely being smart comedic writers with the 'shock' of the film reel. 
It isn't about ego; but rather about about irony (i.e.: omg. wouldn't it be 
shockingly ironic and funny if we did 'this'!?!?) That said, I do find your 
interpretation about overly sensitive black people interesting though ... 
But maybe I'm just being sensitive.LoL Good night, Dude.
comments.author: Melissa M

comments.text:
+Melissa M The man isn't who they thought he was, hence the negative 
reaction from the family and friends of the decesed. Another example of 
this could be a white male conservative who was a porn star in the 60s. 
Dont think just because people are this colour, or that colour, they dont 
have egotistical problems like the rest of us.
comments.author: Bob Loblaw

comments.text:
+Bob Loblaw
No Bob: they aren't making fun of 'overly sensitive black people'. They are 
making fun of, as Michael Sandoval said above, the only roles that black 
people were given, while adding an ironic twist that a celebrated 
activist/leader secretly played those roles in his past. But I would 
venture to say that the film reel was just smart comedians being comedians 
... and not actually making a 'social commentary', other than to be 
shocking, and funny. Hope you are well! LoL
comments.author: Melissa M

comments.text:
+Michael Sandoval This stuff happened in the past and it was disgraceful. 
It would be truly shocking and infuriating if this stuff was still going on 
today, but it isn't. That is why I don't find this video shocking.

comments.text:
Your right, I'd rather be in famine infested Africa than living in America

make it up to us, I will never forgive them for something that happened 
hundreds of years ago. No matter how many blood lines have passed since it 
happened, I can still remember when my great great great great grandfather 
was in shackles, and I shiver every time. Through my fathers sperm I can 
remember the segregation that we faced in those years of terrible 
difficulty as we marched through Washington. I apologize for all of the 
sarcasm in these statements I have made I had to let it all out. Shout out 
to all my white homies!

comments.author: brian common

comments.text:
+McRad
Yes, who was it that said -- I think Chris Rock -- that white people woke 
up and realised what the hell they were doing and changed it. Yes, no issue 
with that.
But this: "Black people now have the same opportunities as whites..." while 
perhaps true in theory, insomuch as there is no formal segregation in law, 
it remains left to be fully realised in practise. Discrimination still 
exists; prejudice still exists; stereotypes still exist; voter registration 
laws still exist. Running around declaring that "it's all fixed now" is 
neither helpful nor true.
Until the US is prepared to discuss what problems remain, those problems 
will remain.
comments.author: ara9ond

comments.text:
This isn't the 1800s or the '60s anymore. If you're having problems with

comments.text:
Lets blame blacks for selling the slaves, or creating child armies.  
Slaughters and starvation in Rwanda and Somalia.

Would you claim that as your beliefs or say you support that because people 
of your same race commit or have committed those?

Don't push the abhorrent mistakes of forefathers into modern times, to 
blame those who no longer hold onto those beliefs not only hinder true 
progress, but halt understanding cold.  Black blames white, White blames 
black, Blacks feels guilty, Whites feel guilty. Blacks grow in retaliation 
and hatred, Whites grow in retaliation and hatred.  It will only progress 
as long as people keep blaming others for past atrocities. 

Before we start blaming other people for the way we exist, rich or poor.
Lets work on ourselves personally.


America created slave trades in America, Blacks still have slave trades in 
Africa.
America and Europe realized the inhumanity and fixed it, not Blacks or 
Whites, but Englishmen and Americans.
Africans white and black, are trying to halt that in middle Africa now.

Irregardless of race, support each other, don't be the majority that finds 
it easier to blame others because they're unconscious to their own 
shortcomings.

It only starts wars.

lets be honest--many of them are self-perpetuated. And yet, it's still

comments.author: ara9ond

comments.text:
"It's all your fault"? Why are you attributing what people did so long ago 
to those of us today who are not racist & don't want to be labelled as 
such. I don't treat Germans with contempt because of what my family went 
through in the world wars. It's not my place to do so. If you want to get 
righteous about it then what about forgiveness, which is a scriptural 
commandment? People like you only perpetuate racism. I've had to deal with 
so many people's passive aggressiveness and racist comments in recent years 
for no good reason & you have the cheek to accuse all white people of being 
racist. I refuse to be condemned for something that I had no part in.Nobody 
even knows how many people owned slaves and who did what to whom. I have 
always celebrated our multicultural society but its getting increasingly 
difficult to not get bitter towards certain groups, ironically because of 
continuous racism accusations. If your great grandfather murdered mine does 
that mean I have the right to call you a murderer? Can't you see that your 
kind of attitude only keeps people divided? Your post is so ignorant and 
outrageously offensive.
comments.author: LivingOracles

comments.text:
>A civil rights actvist willingly degraded himself to be an actor 
structured by "black face" comedy.
Actually, it is worth noting that they happened in the other order, he 
being an actor in the 1930/40s (the film is of that era of Hollywood) and 
an activist by the 1960s. So, he didn't "willingly degrade himself", he 
instead developed a "black political conscience" as I think the terminology 
of the time would have it.
